captions.text:
Feeling groggy, tired or
unmotivated in the afternoon?

Using coffee, soda and
energy drinks

we often try to push
through the dreaded long day

yawning through the hours
and fighting the fatigue.

But it just so happens that
the solution

is the very thing we've been trying
to avoid all along,
sleep.
Truth is, the power nap
is perhaps the most effective way
to rejuvenate your brain.

There are four main stages of
your sleep cycle.

The first two are relatively
light sleep,

while the third brings you
 into a deep slumber.

The final stage known as
rapid eye movement,
or REM for short,
is where most of your dreams begin.

The benefits of napping are 
tied to the length
of time in which you are asleep.
Naps 30 minutes in length

generally only allow time to enter
these first stages.
In stage 1, slow eye movement begins

and if woken you often feel as though
you didn't even sleep.

But as you continue into
stage 2
your brain begins to inhibit processing.

and ignores external stimuli that
it deems non-dangerous

in order to relax you 
and give you a tranquil sleep.
It also begins memory consolidation,

in which information you learn
is processed.

Waking out of these stages has
shown benefits including;
increased productivity,
increased cognitive function,
enhanced memory,
boosted creativity

and most importantly,
feeling less tired.

Beyond 30 minutes you
enter stage 3

and experience something known as
sleep inertia when awakened.

Because your body is 
coming out of a deep sleep,
motor dexterity is decreased

while grogginess and the longing
to go back to sleep increases.

Many people falsely deem naps
non-beneficial for themselves,

but the truth is,
they have simply napped too long.

As the benefits of napping
become clearer

many nap salons have opened
throughout Japan,

where workers can pay to have a
brief lunchtime nap on a daybed
to increase alertness at work.

So maybe it's about time we all 
start sleeping on the job a little more.
Just tell your boss "Science said so".
Got a burning question you want answered?

Ask it in the comments or on
facebook and twitter.

And subscribe for more
weekly science videos.

comments.text:
+Shayaan Choudhry you dont have one dream the entire night. each dream you 
have lasts about 5 minutes in real time, but feels much slower since youre 
asleep, and because its the last thing you remember when you wake up, it 
feels like it was the entire night. so you probably only go into a lucid 
dream during your last cycle of REM sleep, and that's what you remember 
when you wake up
comments.author: Kaleb Logsdon

comments.author: Kaleb Logsdon

comments.text:
+Kaleb Logsdon Time and practice not getting enough sleep as they don't go 
into REM sleep and this builds up so they get it sooner. 
Yeah and if you only take short naps you aren't getting deep sleep and if 
you only sleep for 2 hours then wake up. You also know you have REM sleep 
because you dream. Dreams are when the brain is organizing things and 
nightmares warn us about dangers in your life.
comments.author: clowntrooper61

comments.text:
+clowntrooper61 it TYPICALLY takes an hour or so to go into deep sleep. 
there is something called REM rebound, where your body instantly goes into 
stage 5 sleep, or rem sleep, which is the deepest sleep. most poeple cant 
do this normally, but with enough time and practice, the body adjusts and 
gets used to going into deeper sleep faster. 

and deep sleep isnt just important when youre growing, it's always 
important. during rem sleep your brain does a lot of things such as 
processing new information, mentally practicing things that are important 
or are causing you stress, and repairs cells in your body
comments.author: Kaleb Logsdon

comments.text:
+Kaleb Logsdon Maybe for adults when deep sleep isn't important but when 
you're growing up it is. Deep sleep is where you grow and develop. It takes 
1 hour to 1 and a half to go into deep sleep and that's if you get to bed 
straight away so he isn't going to be growing much than if he got 8 solid 
hours sleep
comments.author: clowntrooper61

comments.text:
+clowntrooper61 it's less about the length of sleep he gets, but rather 
about the depth of sleep. he might go into deep sleep faster, and sleep 
more peacefully, and so rather than sleeping for a long time, he can be 
fine with short bursts of deep sleep. it's actually more productive to do 
it his way, but not many people can do it. and there has been some evidence 
that the human body functions better with multiple short sleep cycles, 
rather than one long sleep cycle, but everybody is different
comments.author: Kaleb Logsdon

comments.text:
You are suppose to have 8 hours sleep solid sleep and although napping

school and still growing, you need as much sleep as you can get in the 
normal sleep cycle as you're disrupting this which is bad for you

found that I was napping while she did and I felt more energized when I 
woke. But, going longer than an hour and it seemed to be much harder to 
wake. This reminded me of when I was a Firefighter and we had "sleeper 
duty". If I had been asleep for more than an hour and less than three when 
the alarm went off, I might not totally wake up until we got to the scene. 
I woke up once standing on the back of the truck next to a fellow 
firefighter that had actually tied me to the hand rail! :D ﻿

comments.text:
*How Long To Nap For The Biggest Brain Benefits*

Taking a nap is like rebooting your brain.  Everyone likes to get a quick 
nap in every now and then, but napping may be as much of an art as it is a 
science. The Wall Street Journal offers recommendations for planning your 
perfect nap, including how long to nap and when.

The sleep experts in the article say a *10-to-20-minute* power nap gives 
you the best “bang for your buck,” but depending on what you want the nap 
to do for you, other durations might be ideal.  For a quick boost of 
alertness, experts say a 10-to-20-minute power nap is adequate for getting 
back to work in a pinch.

For cognitive memory processing, however, a *60-minute nap* may do more 
good, Dr. Mednick said. Including slow-wave sleep helps with remembering 
facts, places and faces. The downside: some grogginess upon waking.

“If you take it* longer than 30 minutes*, you end up in deep sleep. Have 
you ever taken a nap and felt worse when you woke up? That’s what’s 
happening — you’re sleeping too long and you’re going into a stage of sleep 
that’s very difficult to get out of.” – Dr. Michael Breus

Finally, the *90-minute nap* will likely involve a full cycle of sleep, 
which aids creativity and emotional and procedural memory, such as learning 
how to ride a bike. Waking up after REM sleep usually means a minimal 
amount of sleep inertia, Dr. Mednick said.

In fact, a study published in PubMed in 2002 found that napping even for 
5-10 minutes creates a heightened sense of alertness and increased 
cognitive ability in comparison to no nap.  So really, you want to be 
taking a 10-20 minute nap for a quick recharge, or a 60-90 minute nap for a 
deep sleep rejuvenation.

In addition to those recommendations, one surprising suggestion is to *sit 
slightly upright during your nap*, because it will help you avoid a deep 
sleep. And if you find yourself dreaming during your power naps, it may be 
a sign you’re sleep deprived.

The Scientific Power of Naps video﻿

exercise while digesting? Is it better to train endurance with dehydration 
or with hydration? Is it better to work out in hot or cold temperature? Is 
it better to exercise intensely for about 30 minutes or slowly do the same 
amount of exercise during the day? Is powerade or gatorade really helping 
me more than water? Is it fine to exercise with sore muscles? Does 
exercising really slow down growth in teenagers? Is it better to run for 15 
minutes or swim for 15 minutes? Is exercising before sleep bad? What can 
boost your energy when you don't feel like exercising? Does screaming or 
like making a grunting sound while your about to finish a race help you go 
faster or wastes energy? Are snacks in between meals better than 3 separate 
meals (all same amount of food)? What are the best eating methods?(I heard 
eat big breakfast, smaller lunch, and smallest dinner which is the complete 
opposite of what normal people do) I would appreciate it so much if you 
answer any of these questions and I love your videos they are so 
interesting and amazing. I think that watching one of your videos makes me 
learn more than a whole week of school. I know that these are mostly 
exercising and healthy questions its just that im trying to become an 
Olympian and Im sure that your help will definitely boost my career! Thank 
you so much!!!!!﻿

comments.text:
Hm. Is it normal to feel like you've been asleep for hours when you take a 
20 minute nap? I always feel like I've been asleep for a seriously long 
time. ﻿
comments.author: Sonic Mills

comments.text:
Are you feeling the effects of daylight savings? Are you feeling tired 
right now, and unmotivated in the afternoon? Do you know what the solution 
is? A quick power nap! It’s one of the most effective ways to rejuvenate 
your brain and increase your productivity. Don’t believe me? Check out this 
short clip on the scientific power of the nap.
 ﻿
